> Is 8.x compatible with 7.x

No, 8.x uses a brand new protocol, so you have to update both backend and agents, and storage data are not compatible as well (you need to erase the storage data)
You don't need to keep update your branch. You could focus on your plugin and tests. We just need the sync before merging.

> You don't need to keep update your branch. You could focus on your plugin and tests. We just need the sync before merging.

ok,I  got it.And I will do what you said.
First, you need to create new metrics through the OAL script, then you can set up the alarm for it. Default, there isn't this kind of metrics.

This seems your ElastichSearch having some issue, the data is time-series based if some shards are not available occasionally, then this endpoint will be added again.
Our demo and users have deployed the 8.x multiple times, didn't report this issue. If you could provide more detailed information, would be more helpful.
ps: my ES is 3-nodes cluster which is green health showing in kibana
6.1.0 is a very old version. Why do you still deploy that? The latest release has been 8.1.0. We can't support that old release.
Thanks for your report, this is a bug for backend sampling.
Could you try to send a pull request to fix this? Adding `Math#abs` should be an easy fix.
确实老。 seems i have to update the skw。

@pantovad, I'm able to reproduce a memory leak after looking at the source code you sent. However, I am only able to reproduce this memory leak when I use Vert.x EventBus incorrectly. Based on how I'm reproducing it and the small snippet of source code you sent, it seems to me that you're sending messages to `handleExpiries` and expecting a reply. Based on the source code you sent, it seems by design that there will not be a response sent to `handleExpiries` messages. This appears to be what keeps these spans open.

Can you tell me what EventBus method you're executing which sends a message to `handleExpiries`? Are you using one that supplies a non-null `replyHandler`? If so, I'm not sure this an issue that can be solved on Apache SkyWalking's end. I think the most that could be done is a warning message when a certain threshold is passed. I'm not exactly sure what threshold that would be though considering the amount of memory each un-replied message would require varies wildly (in your case 7k per).
@BFergerson thx vm for your findings. We will try to fix the issue from our side by either providing reply message or change the sender not to expect the reply.
